Award.AwardTitle: Making Academic Change Happen for Emerging Engineering Educators (Workshop Proposal)

Division.LongName: Div Of Engineering Education and Centers

Award.AbstractNarration:
The lack of systemic change in STEM education points to an important problem with the approach that the STEM education community has pursued thus far. Change has been targeted at the course and curriculum levels, focusing on teaching and learning methods and proving their efficacy. While beneficial, these activities have not fostered the strategies - such as motivation, communication, collaboration, and persuasion - that are necessary if individuals wish to enact change on larger, more institutional levels. These change strategies are well documented in the literature of other disciplines, such as organizational psychology and behavior, but have not been brought into the conversation within STEM education in a rigorous, accessible way. The workshop Making Academic Change Happen (MACH) fills the need of academics for research-based skills development and assistance in creating a plan for change. Through targeted working sessions on specific topics (e.g. partnership development, generating buy-in, institutional context, and identity discovery), participants learn research-proven strategies for making large scale change happen on their home campus. The focus group for the 2017 MACH Workshop is emerging engineering educators. The primary experience of graduate training is to be introduced to disciplinary research and then be provided with a means to gain further competence. We have determined, however, that new engineering educators are tasked with developing new courses, curricula, and programs. These initiatives require additional skills or areas of expertise: advising, mentoring, curriculum development, imaginative vision, program assessment, etc. None of these skills are likely addressed in a typical engineering Ph.D. curriculum. For these reasons, we believe that new engineering educators who envision themselves as change agents should work to adopt the disposition and skills of a change agent. Attending the MACH Workshop will help these educators start on their path as engineering education innovators.

The purpose of this workshop is to assist emerging engineering educators in: 1) learning and practicing skills needed to lead change, and 2) preparing working documents around a variety of topics that are necessary to advance a change project. By fostering the development of these skills and mindsets in the very people who must lead change efforts, this workshop promotes meaningful change in STEM higher education. The change projects advanced by the workshop participants are expected to become model programs that can be mined for examples strategies and processes for others hoping to implement similar ideas. These projects reach beyond a single classroom, focusing more on the underlying processes, approaches, or philosophy of STEM education enacted on their campus. By working within the institution's context, the change agents trained during the MACH Workshop will positively impact the student experience of STEM. As part of this research, the emerging engineering educators will be interviewed about their change projects and provided with mentors and support for their change activities. Mentorship will continue to be offered after the workshop is over. The progress on their change projects will also be tracked as they implement the MACH change strategies they learned during the workshop.

POR.DRECONTENT:
With this proposal, we received support from the National Science Foundation to allow 16 emerging engineering educators to attend the 2017 Making Academic Change Happen Workshop (MACH) on the campus of Rose-Hulman Institute of Technology (Terre Haute, IN). Through this effort, we encouraged the adoption of successful change strategies by emerging engineering educators.  These individuals are just entering their fields and are often asked to design and implement important academic change in the form of new curricula, programs, and pedagogies. The three MACH facilitators who were supported by the grant provided mentorship to the emerging engineering educators both during and after MACH.  As a result, we created a growing community of practice in academic change in engineering education.

As a result of attending MACH 2017, the Emerging Engineering Educator award recipients worked toward the achievement of the following outcomes:

1. Knowledge Base: The essential knowledge of change processes, administrative structures, etc. are new arenas for emerging engineering educators who envision change. They must be introduced to the language, ideas, and approaches of research-based change strategies. This workshop translates the research literature on change to essential concepts and introduces meaningful language for emerging engineering educators to use.

2. Skills Development: Emerging engineering educators are often asked to initiate changes as they begin their careers. To accomplish change, they must utilize skills not regularly used in teaching or researchbased academic life. Since these skills are newly acquired, they must be formally practiced. When appropriate, workshop sessions incorporate multiple rounds of practice.

3. Community Enlargement: Emerging engineering educators must have community to act as a sounding board, provide support, and both encourage and challenge ideas. Many emerging engineering educators feel isolated, or hesitate to speak or act due to significant power differentials. By enlarging the community of scholars known to be engaged in change practices, the workshop provides tremendous support for future initiatives.

4. Actionable Change: The workshop allows emerging engineering educators to advance their change projects through direct work on action plans, identification of allies and partners, and meaningful targeted feedback from workshop facilitators. When participants work on their projects at the workshop, they actually have an entire team working on their project simultaneously.

After the workshop concluded, all attendees (both the award recipients and 11 other faculty from 4 US universities) were asked to complete a Participant Survey.  They identified several important strengths of the workshop that contributed to their development as change agents:

--expertise and effectiveness of the MACH facilitators, who answered attendee questions, focused on attendees' change projects, and demonstrated flexibility (such as creating a session mid-workshop to meet attendee needs.  All MACH facilitators are faculty at Rose-Hulman Institute of Technology and are selected for MACH based on their skills as teachers and their experience with change projects of their own;

--the opportunity to join a community of change agents they could learn and draw support from;

--well-designed materials (such as worksheets and activities) that adapted the research literature on change into practical, hands-on activities with tools they can use when they return to their own campuses
